instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-2580: What is 820-2580? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL is another way to say SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL, look at the definition provided for SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL as it applies to .
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. Green light only
threads.message:
hey guys. Been a while since posting. Must of learnt something!
Am now stuck on a old <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2580</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. Seconds away from giving up and this post is my last resort. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not holding and is always changing values. From around 8v to 12.6v. 
F7040 is fine and I even changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> off a working board. Same result. 
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> are those sense resistors. I don't quite understand how they work although the readings seem fine. Can't find any shorts.
Possible for some nudges in the right direction??
Thaks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. Green light only
threads.message: Measure resistance between pin 17/18 and between pin 27/28 from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. Green light only
threads.message: can close this. I fkd the board good and proper. Made a fire

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. Green light only
threads.message:
So here's an update.. ended up repalacing the board that caught fire. Bought a supposedly working board from eBay, Rnrcomputers to be precise. Long story short. This board doesn't work either. Has no green orange light. 

Took 3 weeks to arrive and really don't have time to send it back and wait so I thought I'd diagnose. Found <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSI_R_N</SIGNAL> between <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> missing. Jumped it. Got a green light and laptop powers up and all works bar an x for the battery. 

So the smc is not seeing the battery I'm guessing.. And pins 4 and 6 on the battery connector are the lines that tell the smc there is a battery?? Am I on the track?

<CHIP>U4900</CHIP> creates <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL</SIGNAL> and goes to battery then to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

i cant find any other tracks not present. Is this a dead <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? Proper brain stuck now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. Green light only
threads.message: So this is obviously a liquid damaged board you got. In most cases no battery recognized is a dead SMC and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Did you test with a good battery? Yours could have died in the fire with the other board. Also the battery indicator can cause issues, disconnect it to be sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. Green light only
threads.message:
Thanks Duke, I think your right, it does seem so.. I'm going with dead, I tested with two working original batteries. Only had a fan, dc port and battery connected too.
Probably best off doing an eBay return at this point. It cost me $675AU!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. Green light only
threads.message: actually probably try changing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> first I reckon

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. Green light only
threads.message:
One last go...
<RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> is 3.4v <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> is .5v
i don't have a working oscilloscope to know if pins 2 of <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> are doing what they are supposed to do right now either.

Changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>. Something is fucking up the data lines.
